summary: Mixing techniques that balance layers for clarity, prevent ear fatigue, and ensure dialogue remains intelligible while maintaining engagement.

core_principles.description: Dialogue must cut through mix clearly as primary information carrier
Carve frequency pockets to prevent layers from competing audibly
Balance loud and quiet moments to prevent ear fatigue and maintain engagement
Automatically lower music when dialogue occurs for intelligibility
Maintain consistent levels with dialogue peaks at appropriate dB targets

techniques.name: Audio Ducking
techniques.description: Automatically lowering music volume when dialogue occurs for clarity
implementation: Use sidechain compression triggered by dialogue track
Set threshold to engage when speaker begins
Apply reduction of 6-15dB on music track during dialogue
Set attack fast (10-50ms) for quick response
Set release smooth (200-500ms) for natural recovery
Manual ducking as alternative: keyframe music volume manually
Ensure music doesn't pump noticeably
Return to full music level between speaking
examples: Dialogue speaking → music dips −12dB → silence → music returns
Music-heavy section → speaker starts → duck → speaker stops → music back

pros_cons.pro: Ensures dialogue clarity without constant adjustments
pros_cons.con: Poor settings cause pumping, unnatural sound

techniques.name: EQ Pockets and Frequency Management
techniques.description: Carving frequency space in music to prevent competition with dialogue frequencies
implementation: Identify dialogue frequency range (mainly 1-4kHz)
Apply EQ to music: cut 1kHz-3kHz range by 3-6dB
Create pocket for voice to sit clearly in mix
Cut music at 200-300Hz (mud region
Boost presence in music at 5-8kHz for brightness
Use EQ to manage low end (below 80Hz) to prevent boominess
Apply EQ differently to different music elements
Test EQ settings with dialogue playing
techniques.timing: Continuous EQ settings on music track
examples: Music EQ: cut 2-4kHz −5dB for dialogue clarity
Bass boost 80-120Hz, cut 200-300Hz to reduce mud
Treble boost 8-10kHz for sparkle in music
tools: Stock EQ in all major DAWs

pros_cons.pro: Clear dialogue without pumping volume effects
pros_cons.con: Poor EQ can make music sound boxy or weak

pros_cons.pro: Creates space for multiple audio layers
pros_cons.con: Requires ear and practice to set correctly

techniques.name: Dynamic Range Management
techniques.description: Balancing loud and quiet moments to prevent ear fatigue and maintain engagement
implementation: Avoid constant 100% intensity (causes ear fatigue
Create quiet moments for emphasis (dynamic contrast)
Use compression to control extreme peaks
Set target loudness (−16 LUFS for YouTube)
Allow dynamic range: −24 to −6 LUFS peaks
Match dialogue loudness to platform standards
Use mastering limiter to prevent clipping
Export with appropriate loudness targets
examples: Music peaks at −12LUFS, dips to −20LUFS between speakers
Limit peaks to −0.3dBFS to prevent clipping

techniques.name: Dialogue Enhancement Processing
techniques.description: Processing dialogue for clarity, presence, and professional polish
implementation: Compression: 2:1 to 4:1 ratio to control dynamics
EQ: boost 2-5kHz for clarity, cut below 80Hz to reduce rumble
De-esser: tame sibilance at 5-8kHz range
Subtle saturation: adds warmth and thickens sound
Noise reduction: apply gently if needed
Consistent levels: normalize or gain match dialogue
Presence: slight boost around 3kHz for intelligibility
Final polish: limiter to prevent peaks above −6dB
techniques.timing: Processing applied continuously to dialogue track
examples: Voiceover: compressor 3:1, EQ boost 3kHz +3dB, de-esser at 6kHz
Interview recording: noise reduction first, then compression, then EQ
Studio recording: compression, EQ, minimal saturation

pros_cons.pro: Respects viewer's ability to understand content

techniques.name: SFX Balance and Placement
techniques.description: Mixing sound effects to provide punctuation without overpowering content
implementation: Peak SFX at −10dB to −15dB (depending on importance)
Use stereo panning for spatial positioning
Match SFX volume to visual impact magnitude
Apply EQ to prevent SFX from clashing with dialogue
Use reverb on SFX for environment matching
Time SFX precisely to visual actions (frame accuracy)
Layer multiple SFX elements for complexity
Automate SFX levels throughout timeline
techniques.timing: Synced to visual actions, levels variable
examples: Text pop: sound at −12dB, center pan
Whoosh transition: stereo pan left to right, −15dB peak
Impact sound: −10dB, slight reverb for weight
tools: Audio ducking with SFX as triggers
